newsitem.title: INDIA: India's IRFC aims for $150 mln foreign borrowing.
newsitem.headline: India's IRFC aims for $150 mln foreign borrowing.

text.p: State-run Indian Railway Finance Corporation (IRFC) has sought the government's approval to raise $150 million in foreign borrowings in 1997/98 (April-March), the Railway Board's chairman said on Wednesday.

"We have...asked for $150 million in external commercial borrowings," M.K. Kaw told a news conference held after Railways Minister Ram Vilas Paswan presented the railway budget for 1997/98 to parliament.
However, the government's approval would depend on the borrowing needs of other infrastructure sectors like telecommunications, Kaw said.

Paswan said the IRFC would raise 21.5 billion rupees ($600 million) from the domestic and foreign markets in 1997/98, compared with an estimated 18.5 billion in 1996/97, of which 15 billion rupees have already been raised.
Of the amount expected to be raised in the domestic market, five billion rupees were expected to come from tax-free bonds, the same amount as in 1996/97, Kaw said.
Kaw said market borrowings were usually not considered conducive for railway projects since they involved a public utility that did not have profit as its sole motive.
IRFC enjoyed a good credit rating which was helpful but the government was keen not to increase its borrowing liablilities, Kaw said.
"Our credit rating is high...but the difficulty is that we cannot come under a debt trap," he said.
